# 9.1 Using Movement to Feel Better ## Learning Objectives By the end of this session, you'll be able to: - Name how stress shows up in your body - Show 3 ways to use movement to feel less stressed - Pick the best stress-relief moves for your needs ## Materials Needed - Comfortable clothes that allow free movement - Small open space (at least 4x4 feet) - Carpet or rug for better balance (optional) - Water bottle - Paper and pencil for tracking stress signals and creating your plan - Wall or bed for support during breathing exercises ## What is Stress? Your body reacts when you face challenges or threats - that's stress. Everyone deals with it! It might hit before tests, during arguments with friends, or when you try new things. %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Add a two paragraphs so that it doesn't read like AI writing. Remember this is suppose to be read] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%%
Stress changes your body in noticeable ways: - Muscles tighten up - Heart pumps faster - Breathing becomes quick and shallow - Thoughts scatter, making focus difficult %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Insert a focused checkpoint within the markers ---stopandreflect--- and ---stopandreflectEND---, crafting a brief moment that invites learners to pause and consider how the concept connects to their existing knowledge or experience. Format the checkpoint with bold "CHECKPOINT:" text followed by a thought-provoking question that encourages internal processing without requiring written responses or specific activities.] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% ## How Movement Helps Beat Stress %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Add a two paragraphs so that it doesn't read like AI writing. Remember this is suppose to be read] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% Moving around works wonders against stress! Here's why: ### Feel-Good Brain Chemicals Exercise triggers your brain to release endorphins. These natural chemicals lift your mood and help you relax. %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Add a two paragraphs so that it doesn't read like AI writing. Remember this is suppose to be read] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% ### Burns Off Extra Energy Stress often creates jumpiness in your body. Physical activity uses up this extra energy, leaving you calmer.%%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Add a two paragraphs so that it doesn't read like AI writing. Remember this is suppose to be read] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% ### Helps You Sleep Better Moving regularly improves how quickly you fall asleep and how well you rest. Good sleep makes stress easier to handle.%%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Add a two paragraphs so that it doesn't read like AI writing. Remember this is suppose to be read] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% ### Takes Your Mind Off Worries Focusing on physical movement gives your brain a break from stress-causing thoughts.%%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Add a two paragraphs so that it doesn't read like AI writing. Remember this is suppose to be read] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% ## Stress-Busting Moves You Can Try at Home Let's explore some activities that help when stress builds up. No fancy equipment needed!%%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Add a two paragraphs so that it doesn't read like AI writing. Remember this is suppose to be read] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% ### 1. Tension Release Stretches %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Insert an "Audio Instructions" section within the markers ---audioinstructions--- and ---audioinstructionsEND---. Create this based on the content that follows this instruction block. The section should include a heading "### Audio Instructions: " followed by a brief title that describes the key action or concept being explained (e.g., "How to Skip" should be replaced with an appropriate title based on the following content). Then include a URL in this format: https://api.learnstage.com/media-manager/api/access/exceled/default/lms/courses/1648/podcasts/X-X-Y.mp3 where X-X should match the lesson number found at the top of the document (e.g., "2.1" would become "2-1"), and Y should be a sequential number starting with 1 for the first audio instruction in the file, 2 for the second, etc. Place this section at the appropriate point in the content where audio guidance would be most helpful.] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% **What you need:** Your body and arm-stretching space (about 3 feet around you) **Time needed:** About 5 minutes at your own pace **Setup instructions:** - Find a spot where you won't bump into furniture - Wear comfortable clothes that let you move freely - Stand on a carpet or rug for better balance Follow these steps: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart 2. Breathe in while lifting shoulders toward ears 3. Hold for 3 seconds, noticing the tension 4. Exhale and drop shoulders, letting tension go 5. Repeat 5 times 6. Try with other body parts - clench fists then release, scrunch face then relax **Success check:** You've done this correctly when you feel the difference between tension and relaxation in each body part. **Troubleshooting:** - If you feel dizzy: Slow down your breathing or try sitting instead of standing - If you don't feel much difference: Exaggerate the tension more when you tighten up **Safety tip:** Stop if it hurts. You should feel a gentle stretch, not pain. ### 2. Energy Burners %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Insert an "Audio Instructions" section within the markers ---audioinstructions--- and ---audioinstructionsEND---. Create this based on the content that follows this instruction block. The section should include a heading "### Audio Instructions: " followed by a brief title that describes the key action or concept being explained (e.g., "How to Skip" should be replaced with an appropriate title based on the following content). Then include a URL in this format: https://api.learnstage.com/media-manager/api/access/exceled/default/lms/courses/1648/podcasts/X-X-Y.mp3 where X-X should match the lesson number found at the top of the document (e.g., "2.1" would become "2-1"), and Y should be a sequential number starting with 1 for the first audio instruction in the file, 2 for the second, etc. Place this section at the appropriate point in the content where audio guidance would be most helpful.] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% **What you need:** Small space for movement (at least 4x4 feet) **Time needed:** Start with 3 minutes, then build up as you get comfortable **Setup instructions:** - Clear away any objects you might trip over - Have water nearby for when you get thirsty - Wear shoes if you're on a hard floor Pick from these quick activities: - Jumping jacks - Start with 10, then rest. Do 3 sets. - Invisible jump rope - Pretend to jump rope for 30 seconds, rest for 15 seconds. Repeat 4 times. - Dance party - Play a favorite song and move however you want for the whole song! **Success check:** You'll know it's working when: - Your breathing gets faster - You feel warmer - Your mind feels clearer after finishing **Modifications for different needs:** - Need quiet? Try "silent" versions: Step side to side instead of jumping, or do slow-motion movements - Limited space? March in place or do seated arm circles - Different abilities? Stay seated and do arm movements to the same rhythm ### 3. Calm-Down Breathing %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Insert an "Audio Instructions" section within the markers ---audioinstructions--- and ---audioinstructionsEND---. Create this based on the content that follows this instruction block. The section should include a heading "### Audio Instructions: " followed by a brief title that describes the key action or concept being explained (e.g., "How to Skip" should be replaced with an appropriate title based on the following content). Then include a URL in this format: https://api.learnstage.com/media-manager/api/access/exceled/default/lms/courses/1648/podcasts/X-X-Y.mp3 where X-X should match the lesson number found at the top of the document (e.g., "2.1" would become "2-1"), and Y should be a sequential number starting with 1 for the first audio instruction in the file, 2 for the second, etc. Place this section at the appropriate point in the content where audio guidance would be most helpful.] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% **What you need:** Any spot where you can sit or lie down comfortably **Time needed:** 3-5 minutes minimum **Setup instructions:** - Find a quiet spot away from distractions - Turn off or silence your phone - Sit against a wall or lie on your bed for support Steps to follow: 1. Sit comfortably or lie on your back 2. Rest one hand on your belly 3. Inhale slowly through your nose for 4 counts (belly expands) 4. Hold for 2 counts 5. Exhale slowly through your mouth for 6 counts 6. Continue for at least 10 cycles **Success check:** You're doing it right when: - Your hand on your belly rises when you breathe in - Your breathing slows down - Your thoughts become less jumpy - You feel more relaxed after 10 cycles **Troubleshooting:** - Mind wandering? Gently bring attention back to counting your breaths - Can't breathe deeply? Start with shorter counts (2 in, 1 hold, 3 out) - Feeling anxious? Open your eyes and focus on something in the room ## Know Your Stress Signals %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Add a two paragraphs so that it doesn't read like AI writing. Remember this is suppose to be read] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% Everyone experiences stress differently. Recognizing your personal signals helps you catch stress early before it gets too intense! ### Body Scan Activity %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% [Insert an "Audio Instructions" section within the markers ---audioinstructions--- and ---audioinstructionsEND---. Create this based on the content that follows this instruction block. The section should include a heading "### Audio Instructions: " followed by a brief title that describes the key action or concept being explained (e.g., "How to Skip" should be replaced with an appropriate title based on the following content). Then include a URL in this format: https://api.learnstage.com/media-manager/api/access/exceled/default/lms/courses/1648/podcasts/X-X-Y.mp3 where X-X should match the lesson number found at the top of the document (e.g., "2.1" would become "2-1"), and Y should be a sequential number starting with 1 for the first audio instruction in the file, 2 for the second, etc. Place this section at the appropriate point in the content where audio guidance would be most helpful.] %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%% Take 2 minutes right now to check your body:
1. Sit comfortably and close your eyes if that feels okay 2. Starting at your head, slowly move your attention down your body 3. At each part (head, jaw, shoulders, chest, stomach, hands, legs), notice: - Any tightness or tension? - Any uncomfortable sensations? - Any parts that feel different from normal? 4. On a piece of paper, write down or draw where you felt tension **My Personal Stress Signals Chart:** | Body Area | What I Notice When Stressed | |-----------|------------------------------| | Head | (Example: Headache behind eyes) | | Jaw | | | Shoulders | | | Chest | | | Stomach | | | Hands | | | Thoughts | |
Keep this chart where you can see it daily. When you notice these signals, it's time to use one of your movement activities! ## Your Personal Stress-Busting Plan Now that you understand how movement helps with stress, let's create your own plan: **Step 1: Choose Your Activities** Fill in this chart with the activities that seem most helpful for different situations: | When I Need To... | Activity I'll Try | Where I'll Do It | How Long | |-------------------|-------------------|------------------|----------| | Calm down quickly | | | | | Release built-up energy | | | | | Relax before bed | | | | **Step 2: Test Your Plan** Pick one activity from your chart to try today: 1. Before starting, rate your stress level from 1-5 (5 being highest) 2. Do the activity for the time you planned 3. After finishing, rate your stress level again 4. Write down what changed: _______________________ **Step 3: Adjust Based on Results** If your stress level dropped, great! If not, try: - A different activity - Doing the same activity longer - Combining two activities (like energy burning followed by calm breathing) ## Need Help? If stress feels overwhelming, that's normal! Talk to a trusted adult like a parent, teacher, or school counselor. They can suggest more ways to handle stress. **Remember:** It's okay if one activity doesn't work every time. Having multiple options gives you the best chance of feeling better! ---keytakeaways--- ## Key Takeaways - Your body shows stress through physical signals like tight muscles and fast breathing, and using movement activities can help release these tensions. - Different types of movement help in different ways - tension release stretches loosen tight muscles, energy burners use up nervous energy, and calm-down breathing slows your heart rate. - Creating a personal stress-busting plan helps you respond quickly when you notice your unique stress signals, giving you control over how you feel. ---keytakeawaysEND---
instructions:
You are a specialized content generator working with a markdown document that contains embedded content generation instructions. These instructions are clearly marked with the delimiters %%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% and %%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%%.

Your primary task:
1. Process the document sequentially, identifying all properly formatted instruction blocks
2. For each valid instruction block:
   - Thoroughly analyze the requested content specifications
   - Generate content that precisely fulfills these specifications
   - Replace ONLY the instruction block (including delimiters) with your generated content
   - Ensure seamless integration with surrounding text

IMPORTANT - PRESERVED MARKERS:
The document contains special marker tags that MUST be preserved exactly as they appear:
- ---stopandreflect--- and ---stopandreflectEND---
- ---checkyourunderstanding--- and ---checkyourunderstandingEND---
- ---keytakeaways--- and ---keytakeawaysEND---
These markers serve specific pedagogical functions in the document and are NOT instruction blocks for you to replace. Always leave these markers completely intact.

EXAMPLE OF CONTENT REPLACEMENT:
Consider this example extract:

Original text with instruction block:
```
Learning to code requires practice and attention to detail.

%%%CONTENT_REQUEST%%% 
[Add a linking paragraph so that it doesn't read like ai writing. remember this is suppose to be read]

When creating algorithms and programming sequences, several common errors can occur:
%%%CONTENT_REQUEST_END%%%

Understanding these errors helps troubleshoot more efficiently.
```

Proper response after processing:
```
Learning to code requires practice and attention to detail.

As you progress in your coding journey, you'll find yourself moving from basic syntax to more complex logical structures. This transition often reveals patterns in problem-solving that extend beyond mere code writing into the realm of computational thinking.

When creating algorithms and programming sequences, several common errors can occur:

Understanding these errors helps troubleshoot more efficiently.
```

In this example:
- The entire instruction block (including delimiters and the instruction in brackets) was replaced
- The generated content creates a natural bridge between the existing paragraphs
- The writing style matches the instructional tone of the document
- No trace of the instruction itself remains in the final text

Content generation guidelines:
- Maintain consistent tone, style, and technical depth with the surrounding document
- Preserve all terminology and naming conventions established in the document
- Ensure logical flow between paragraphs before and after your insertions
- Adapt formatting to match the document's established patterns

Critical requirements:
- Do NOT modify ANY text outside the instruction blocks
- Do NOT add commentary about the instructions or your generation process
- Do NOT create new instruction blocks or modify existing delimiter syntax
- If an instruction is unclear or contradictory, interpret it in the way that best serves the document's apparent purpose

Error handling:
- If you encounter nested or malformed instruction blocks, process only the outermost valid block
- If an instruction seems impossible to fulfill based on the context, provide the closest reasonable approximation

The final document should appear as a cohesive whole with no trace of the instruction blocks or generation process, while preserving all special marker tags intact.
context:
# Preparatory Context for Content Enhancement

## Content Summary
The current content is an educational module focused on using physical movement to manage stress. It covers the physiological effects of stress, the benefits of different types of movement-based stress relief activities, and guidance for creating a personalized stress-management plan. The content is structured with clear learning objectives, materials needed, and step-by-step instructions for several stress-busting exercises.

## Enhancement Requirements
The key objectives for enhancing this content are to:
1. Improve the narrative flow and cohesion between paragraphs to create a more natural, conversational tone.
2. Expand on the explanations and examples provided for each stress relief activity to give learners a more comprehensive understanding.
3. Incorporate more interactive elements, such as reflection checkpoints and self-assessment opportunities, to actively engage the learner.
4. Ensure all content is appropriately adapted for the target middle school audience in terms of language, complexity, and relevance.

## Target Learner Considerations
- **Age Range:** 11-14 years old (grades 6-8)
- **Reading Level:** 5th-6th grade on Flesch-Kincaid scale
- **Prior Knowledge:** Varying exposure to physical education concepts, possibly limited formal PE instruction
- **Learning Style:** Visual demonstrations, simple explanations, hands-on activities
- **Physical Space/Equipment:** Limited access to specialized equipment, varying home spaces available

The content should use language and examples that are familiar and relatable to middle school students. Explanations should be concise and direct, with a focus on practical application. Incorporate more visual elements, such as diagrams and illustrations, to support the kinesthetic learning preferences of the target audience.

## Learning Medium Considerations
This content is intended for asynchronous online delivery through Excel Middle School's curriculum, with no opportunities for peer interaction. As such, the enhanced version should be self-contained and designed for independent learning. Formatting and structure should prioritize clear organization, frequent visual breaks, and accessibility for learners working in diverse home environments.

## Key Considerations
- Maintain the educational integrity and core purpose of the original content
- Enhance the narrative flow and cohesion to create a more natural, conversational tone
- Expand on the explanations and examples for each stress relief activity
- Incorporate more interactive elements to actively engage the learner
- Ensure all content is appropriately adapted for the target middle school audience

## Suggested Approach
1. Review the current content to fully understand the key themes, concepts, and structure.
2. Analyze the enhancement requirements and target learner profile to identify specific areas for improvement.
3. Enhance the narrative flow by adding transitional paragraphs that bridge ideas and create a more natural progression.
4. Expand on the instructions and examples for each stress relief activity, providing more comprehensive guidance and visual support.
5. Incorporate interactive elements, such as reflection checkpoints and self-assessment opportunities, to engage the learner and reinforce key concepts.
6. Carefully review the adapted content to ensure it aligns with the reading level, language, and learning preferences of the target middle school audience.
7. Format the enhanced content to optimize for the asynchronous online delivery medium, with a focus on clear organization, visual appeal, and accessibility.
response:
# 9.1 Using Movement to Feel Better ## Learning Objectives By the end of this session, you'll be able to: - Name how stress shows up in your body - Show 3 ways to use movement to feel less stressed - Pick the best stress-relief moves for your needs ## Materials Needed - Comfortable clothes that allow free movement - Small open space (at least 4x4 feet) - Carpet or rug for better balance (optional) - Water bottle - Paper and pencil for tracking stress signals and creating your plan - Wall or bed for support during breathing exercises ## What is Stress? Your body reacts when you face challenges or threats - that's stress. Everyone deals with it! It might hit before tests, during arguments with friends, or when you try new things. Think about the last time you felt nervous about something important. Maybe your heart started racing, or your stomach felt funny. That's your body's alarm system kicking in! This reaction helped our ancestors survive dangerous situations like encountering wild animals. Today, we face different kinds of challenges - like pop quizzes or trying out for sports teams - but our bodies still respond in similar ways. Understanding these reactions is the first step to managing them better, which is exactly what we'll learn in this lesson.
Stress changes your body in noticeable ways: - Muscles tighten up - Heart pumps faster - Breathing becomes quick and shallow - Thoughts scatter, making focus difficult ---stopandreflect--- **CHECKPOINT:** Take a moment to notice - where in your body do you usually feel stress first? Is it a knot in your stomach, tension in your shoulders, or something else? ---stopandreflectEND--- ## How Movement Helps Beat Stress Have you ever noticed how much better you feel after running around with friends or dancing to your favorite song? There's actually science behind why movement makes us feel good when we're stressed out! When we're worried or anxious, all that stress energy gets trapped in our bodies. Movement gives us a healthy way to release it. It's like opening a pressure valve that lets out the steam before the pot boils over! Moving around works wonders against stress! Here's why: ### Feel-Good Brain Chemicals Exercise triggers your brain to release endorphins. These natural chemicals lift your mood and help you relax. Think of endorphins as your body's built-in mood boosters. They're like little messengers that travel through your body saying, "Hey, everything's going to be okay!" Even a quick five-minute dance break can start releasing these helpful chemicals. The best part is that you don't need to run a marathon to get these benefits. Simple activities like stretching, walking, or even jumping jacks can trigger this positive reaction in your brain. ### Burns Off Extra Energy Stress often creates jumpiness in your body. Physical activity uses up this extra energy, leaving you calmer. Have you ever felt so nervous that you couldn't sit still? That's your body filling up with stress energy that needs somewhere to go. It's like having a fully charged battery with no device to power - that energy is just waiting to be used! When you move your body through exercise or play, you're using up that extra charge. After a good movement session, that jittery, can't-sit-still feeling often disappears because you've given that energy a healthy outlet. ### Helps You Sleep Better Moving regularly improves how quickly you fall asleep and how well you rest. Good sleep makes stress easier to handle. When you're active during the day, your body is more ready for rest when bedtime comes around. It's like your body thinks, "Wow, we did a lot today! Time to recharge!" This helps you fall asleep faster and stay asleep longer. Better sleep is super important because your brain processes stress while you rest. Think of it as your brain's nightly clean-up crew, sorting through the day's worries and filing them away properly. When you sleep well, you wake up with a clearer mind and more energy to handle whatever challenges come your way. ### Takes Your Mind Off Worries Focusing on physical movement gives your brain a break from stress-causing thoughts. When you're concentrating on learning a new dance move or trying to keep your balance during a yoga pose, your brain shifts attention away from worries. It's hard to stress about tomorrow's math test when you're counting jumping jacks or focusing on your breathing! This mental break is like pressing the reset button on your thoughts. Even a short activity can interrupt the cycle of worry that sometimes gets stuck on repeat in our minds. After moving your body, you might find that problems that seemed huge before don't bother you quite as much. ## Stress-Busting Moves You Can Try at Home Let's explore some activities that help when stress builds up. No fancy equipment needed! The great thing about these exercises is that you can do them almost anywhere - in your bedroom, living room, or even a quiet corner at school. You don't need to change clothes or set aside a huge chunk of time. These activities are like having stress-relief tools in your pocket, ready whenever you need them. Some work better for different situations, so having a variety to choose from means you'll always have something that fits your needs in the moment. ### 1. Tension Release Stretches ---audioinstructions--- ### Audio Instructions: Releasing Body Tension Through Stretching https://api.learnstage.com/media-manager/api/access/exceled/default/lms/courses/1648/podcasts/9-1-1.mp3 ---audioinstructionsEND--- **What you need:** Your body and arm-stretching space (about 3 feet around you) **Time needed:** About 5 minutes at your own pace **Setup instructions:** - Find a spot where you won't bump into furniture - Wear comfortable clothes that let you move freely - Stand on a carpet or rug for better balance Follow these steps: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart 2. Breathe in while lifting shoulders toward ears 3. Hold for 3 seconds, noticing the tension 4. Exhale and drop shoulders, letting tension go 5. Repeat 5 times 6. Try with other body parts - clench fists then release, scrunch face then relax **Success check:** You've done this correctly when you feel the difference between tension and relaxation in each body part. **Troubleshooting:** - If you feel dizzy: Slow down your breathing or try sitting instead of standing - If you don't feel much difference: Exaggerate the tension more when you tighten up **Safety tip:** Stop if it hurts. You should feel a gentle stretch, not pain. ### 2. Energy Burners ---audioinstructions--- ### Audio Instructions: Quick Energy-Burning Activities https://api.learnstage.com/media-manager/api/access/exceled/default/lms/courses/1648/podcasts/9-1-2.mp3 ---audioinstructionsEND--- **What you need:** Small space for movement (at least 4x4 feet) **Time needed:** Start with 3 minutes, then build up as you get comfortable **Setup instructions:** - Clear away any objects you might trip over - Have water nearby for when you get thirsty - Wear shoes if you're on a hard floor Pick from these quick activities: - Jumping jacks - Start with 10, then rest. Do 3 sets. - Invisible jump rope - Pretend to jump rope for 30 seconds, rest for 15 seconds. Repeat 4 times. - Dance party - Play a favorite song and move however you want for the whole song! **Success check:** You'll know it's working when: - Your breathing gets faster - You feel warmer - Your mind feels clearer after finishing **Modifications for different needs:** - Need quiet? Try "silent" versions: Step side to side instead of jumping, or do slow-motion movements - Limited space? March in place or do seated arm circles - Different abilities? Stay seated and do arm movements to the same rhythm ### 3. Calm-Down Breathing ---audioinstructions--- ### Audio Instructions: Guided Calm-Down Breathing Exercise https://api.learnstage.com/media-manager/api/access/exceled/default/lms/courses/1648/podcasts/9-1-3.mp3 ---audioinstructionsEND--- **What you need:** Any spot where you can sit or lie down comfortably **Time needed:** 3-5 minutes minimum **Setup instructions:** - Find a quiet spot away from distractions - Turn off or silence your phone - Sit against a wall or lie on your bed for support Steps to follow: 1. Sit comfortably or lie on your back 2. Rest one hand on your belly 3. Inhale slowly through your nose for 4 counts (belly expands) 4. Hold for 2 counts 5. Exhale slowly through your mouth for 6 counts 6. Continue for at least 10 cycles **Success check:** You're doing it right when: - Your hand on your belly rises when you breathe in - Your breathing slows down - Your thoughts become less jumpy - You feel more relaxed after 10 cycles **Troubleshooting:** - Mind wandering? Gently bring attention back to counting your breaths - Can't breathe deeply? Start with shorter counts (2 in, 1 hold, 3 out) - Feeling anxious? Open your eyes and focus on something in the room ## Know Your Stress Signals Learning to recognize stress in your body is like having an early warning system. Just like how dark clouds might signal an approaching storm, your body sends its own signals when stress is building up. These signals are different for everyone. Some people get headaches, while others might notice their shoulders tensing up or their stomach feeling upset. By paying attention to your unique stress patterns, you can catch stress early and take action before it gets too overwhelming. Everyone experiences stress differently. Recognizing your personal signals helps you catch stress early before it gets too intense! ### Body Scan Activity ---audioinstructions--- ### Audio Instructions: Guided Body Scan for Stress Awareness https://api.learnstage.com/media-manager/api/access/exceled/default/lms/courses/1648/podcasts/9-1-4.mp3 ---audioinstructionsEND--- Take 2 minutes right now to check your body:
1. Sit comfortably and close your eyes if that feels okay 2. Starting at your head, slowly move your attention down your body 3. At each part (head, jaw, shoulders, chest, stomach, hands, legs), notice: - Any tightness or tension? - Any uncomfortable sensations? - Any parts that feel different from normal? 4. On a piece of paper, write down or draw where you felt tension **My Personal Stress Signals Chart:** | Body Area | What I Notice When Stressed | |-----------|------------------------------| | Head | (Example: Headache behind eyes) | | Jaw | | | Shoulders | | | Chest | | | Stomach | | | Hands | | | Thoughts | |
Keep this chart where you can see it daily. When you notice these signals, it's time to use one of your movement activities! ## Your Personal Stress-Busting Plan Now that you understand how movement helps with stress, let's create your own plan: **Step 1: Choose Your Activities** Fill in this chart with the activities that seem most helpful for different situations: | When I Need To... | Activity I'll Try | Where I'll Do It | How Long | |-------------------|-------------------|------------------|----------| | Calm down quickly | | | | | Release built-up energy | | | | | Relax before bed | | | | **Step 2: Test Your Plan** Pick one activity from your chart to try today: 1. Before starting, rate your stress level from 1-5 (5 being highest) 2. Do the activity for the time you planned 3. After finishing, rate your stress level again 4. Write down what changed: _______________________ **Step 3: Adjust Based on Results** If your stress level dropped, great! If not, try: - A different activity - Doing the same activity longer - Combining two activities (like energy burning followed by calm breathing) ## Need Help? If stress feels overwhelming, that's normal! Talk to a trusted adult like a parent, teacher, or school counselor. They can suggest more ways to handle stress. **Remember:** It's okay if one activity doesn't work every time. Having multiple options gives you the best chance of feeling better! ---keytakeaways--- ## Key Takeaways - Your body shows stress through physical signals like tight muscles and fast breathing, and using movement activities can help release these tensions. - Different types of movement help in different ways - tension release stretches loosen tight muscles, energy burners use up nervous energy, and calm-down breathing slows your heart rate. - Creating a personal stress-busting plan helps you respond quickly when you notice your unique stress signals, giving you control over how you feel. ---keytakeawaysEND---
